Heath, Joseph wrote:

> Isn't the whole point that there is no overhead in Test First. You still
> have to write the tests if you test after. It's just that you're able to
> test *while* coding : I won't list the benefits as they are quite well
> documented..
> joe

Or to put it another way, there is overhead relative to the usual 
approach, which is to *not* test code at all except in a simplistic way. 
In that case, test-first has the advantage of knowing that the code 
actually works.  The same amount of test coverage done after the fact 
will definitely take longer, because programmers will need to study code 
written much earlier to devise good tests.  Moreover, newer layers of 
the code may well have been written based on untested older layers which 
have bugs.

I think the biggest payoff, though, is in maintenance and refactoring. 
Maintenance is a pain on most big systems because you're never sure what 
you'll break when you make a change, especially a change at a low level 
of the system.  If you have a suite of unit tests in place, you'll KNOW 
what you break.  And if you find you broke something untested, you write 
a test, add it to the suite, fix it, and never encounter it again.  This 
also greatly simplifies refactoring, or cleaning the code as you touch 
it - something else avoided in classic systems because you don't know 
what you might break by, say, moving a method or changing a parameter 
type.  With good tests, you can do that without fear.  This adds up to 
*greatly* reduced maintenance costs in the long run.

Quite frankly, the biggest test most programmers apply on most jobs is 
"Does it compile?"  To them, test-first looks like overhead.
